    <li> I&#x27;ve been shaving with Braun electric razors for three decades, and while each new generation gets better, the Series 7 is by far the best in terms of comfort, closeness, and battery life.</li>
    <li> Charged up and used the first time this morning - distinct improvement over the previous Series 7 model [[ASIN:B000Q6SU3C Braun Series 7- 790cc Pulsonic  Shaver]] and 9595 [[ASIN:B000IWFU3W Braun 9595 Series 7 Electric Shaver]] with several modifications recommended by users incorporated into the design:&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;1)  Redesigned head.  No, you do NOT need the old blue strip in the middle - the new Series 7 head is better than the previous model.  Slightly larger diameter holes with irregular shapes, redesigned center cutting strip with rounded guides (contrary to other reviews, cutting surface of the center strip is exactly the same in the new head as the old - 30mm long); it actually cuts better and more comfortably (and cooler for some reason) than the old head design.  Sort of a moot point, because you can use either head design with either shaver series, but nice to see an improved head design come out with this new shaver.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;2) The plastic strip in the back, below the shaver head on the body of the shaver, is now smooth and without lettering.  The reason this is important is because in the OLD design, a rather meaningless \\&quot;CAUTION: Use only with Braun power unit blah, blah\\&quot; is stamped into the case, through the silver paint covering the black plastic body.  That&#x27;s important because over a short period of time, with daily exposure to the alcohol cleaning fluid, the silver paint begins to peel off around the lettering because of the break in the surface, exposing the black plastic below.  Just cosmetic, other than flakes of paint falling into the cleaning unit, but annoying on a high-priced shaver, and it&#x27;s pretty well guaranteed because it happened to all three of my previous Braun units, generally after a couple of months&#x27; use.  The new shaver has the lettering printed on the soft rubber backing, and presumably the unbroken surface of the top strip will not peel.  Still appears to be painted black plastic (in this case with a graphite-colored paint), so the jury is still out on its durability.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;3) Quieter operation.  I would estimate about 20-30% quieter than the older model.  Virtually the same on the cleaning unit as the old one, but the actual \\&quot;noisy\\&quot; part of the cleaning cycle in the cleaner is less than 5 minutes (much shorter than Norelco&#x27;s or Panasonic&#x27;s auto cleaner units); the rest is convection drying and charging, which is completely silent (also unlike Norelco and Panasonic, which use a fan for drying).&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;4) The comfort setting buttons (+ and -) on the body of the shaver actually do work, slowing down or speeding up cycles and vibration on ALL the cutter heads.  The \\&quot;sensitive\\&quot; setting gives the most comfortable shave I have had from a dry shave on my neck and upper lip.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;5)  The \\&quot;Lock\\&quot; button on the head appears to be metal.  Really thin metal, but metal.  The previous design was a plastic button with a tiny pin holding the head locked, which was almost guaranteed to break around the end of the warranty period.  Again, durability remains to be seen, but if it has been reengineered with metal, that&#x27;s a definite plus.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Minuses:  The soft rubber backing (on my new unit) has several gaps between it and the hard plastic body, and seems to be not fitted as well as my older unit.  Doesn&#x27;t appear to be loose, and may again be only cosmetic, but Braun QC is still somewhat lacking.  Customer service with Braun is still a well-reported irritant - if you run into an issue with their shavers you must find a Braun dealer in the nearest STATE that will accept a return of your shaver, and they may not be very user-friendly if you didn&#x27;t purchase from them - caveat emptor; you also cannot return this item to Amazon, unlike other shavers.  The \\&quot;On\\&quot; button is suitable for a night-light.  A really bright night light.  Then again, this may be a plus, depending on whether you keep it on your nightstand and are afraid of the dark.  Lots of painted plastic still, but the shaver doesn&#x27;t feel \\&quot;cheap;\\&quot; just a question of long term wear with use - Panasonic and Norelco shavers seem to be able to use molded plastic that is colored throughout on their units, instead of paint over plastic (actually Braun does too in their lower-end Series 7s); it&#x27;s a curiosity to me why their top-of-the-line shaver retains this archaic Mattel-like production process.  Collectively, Braun loses a star for the above.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;All in all, a definite improvement with a more comfortable shave over the previous Series 7 and 9595 units if you shave dry or with a pre-electric.  Still not as comfortable (to me) as a wet electric shave, but faster, quieter (for a foil), less messy with a closer shave, and I suspect the best of the dry shave lot at this time.t feel \\&quot;cheap;\\&quot; just a question of long term wear with use - Panasonic and Norelco shavers seem to be able to use molded plastic that is colored throughout on their units, instead of paint over plastic (actually Braun does too in their lower-end Series 7s); it&#x27;s a curiosity to me why their top-of-the-line shaver retains this archaic Mattel-like production process. Still not as comfortable (to me) as a wet electric shave, but faster, quieter (for a foil), less messy with a closer shave, and I suspect the best of the dry shave lot at this time.</li>

Going dry-shave, I may give the tiniest of edges to Panasonic over Braun and Norelco, but all three are awfully close  - to each other and in quality of shave.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Speed - If you&#x27;re in a hurry and want to get in and get out with a dry-shave as quickly as possible, the Norelco wins. Norelco&#x27;s apparently has detergent and lubrication. From what I&#x27;ve been able to tell, the Panasonic solution is only a detergent. Manually, the Norelco is easiest to clean and you can duplicate the auto clean by pouring some of its [[ASIN:B002DHVAZW Philips Norelco HQ200 Jet Clean Solution]] in a dish or mug and whirring the shaver in it for 30 seconds after shaving. The Panasonic and Braun can be rinsed off under a faucet. The Panasonic&#x27;s special cleaning speed makes it slightly easier to manually clean than the Braun.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Maneuverability - If you have a moustache, goatee, beard, long sideburns, or whatever this is a very important category. The Braun is king here with the Norelco second and the larger-head Panasonic last.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Noise - You can hardly hear the Norelco at all. The Braun is a little buzzy and the Panasonic loudest although not irritatingly so. Still, a sleeping spouse nearby will appreciate you using the Norelco most.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Travel - The Norelco is last in this category because you&#x27;ll need to bring the charging stand with you. The Norelco soft case does not hold the stand so that&#x27;s a bit of a drawback. The Braun&#x27;s harder case gives it top honors over the Panasonic&#x27;s soft one, but the Panasonic has an on-off lock that the Braun lacks. Perhaps the Braun doesn&#x27;t need it because the case is harder, and also because the Braun is the only shaver that can run while plugged in with a depleted battery. The other two require a 5-minute charge to give you a few minutes shave. A fully-charged shaver gives you about 50 minutes in each.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;OVERALL - They&#x27;re all excellent, but overall I&#x27;d choose the Braun with the auto cleaner. However, the Norelco has, by far, the best trimmer. Because of its rotary heads, it also hits my face at different angles, so I occasionally follow up the Braun with a quick run over with the Norelco. I use the Panasonic strictly as a travel razor. It offers no advantage over the Braun or Norelco, except that it cleans easier if you don&#x27;t have the cleaning station.     <li> I have an unfortunate combination of sensitive skin, a coarse fast-growing beard and very much prone to ingrown hairs. I initially was drawn to the rotary types but they irritated my skin so much and produced mediocre shaves that I switched to foil shavers and really saw an immediate positive change.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Tried each of the following for a minimum of 8 weeks before deciding (Braun 790cc-4, Braun Series 5 570, Panasonic Arc IV ES8249S and the Remington F5 5790) and the one that worked best for me was the Braun Series 7.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;The Braun 790 just felt superb in the hand, build quality was top notch - no flex or give at all, the weight is perfect and the handle feels very secure. The foils float a fair bit beyond the head assembly so nothing makes contact with your face but the foils, and the foils just glide really easily across a dry face, unlike other shavers.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;The trimmer is very effective and I found the curvature of the trimmer helps to get the occasional missed hear, even tiny stubble that the shaver missed on my neck. The three intensity settings are there however I never really found a substantial difference in performance between the three settings so I typically use the most intense.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;The internal battery is a Li-Ion type so there&#x27;s never a need to fully discharge or any maintenance of the sort, there&#x27;s also no battery memory issues of course. The battery charges in under an hour and gives 50 minutes of use. The power cable can be plugged directly into the shaver for plugged-in shaving, for those times when the battery is completely flat. This was important to me as most other shavers I&#x27;ve tried didn&#x27;t allow for plugged-in shaving (possibly due to them being wet/dry shavers?), which meant once the battery was done, so was the shaver.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;I love the Clean and Renew system. It&#x27;s an essential item for this shaver, especially since the Series 7 cutting block and foils are a single unit that cannot be taken apart for a thorough cleaning. You can however release the shaving head unit off the shaver to clean underneath the cutting block but with the Clean and Renew system none of that is necessary. It cleans the shaver thoroughly, lubricates it and dries it in about 30 minutes. The process is a little loud but not uncomfortably so. To top it off, the shaver smells great every time. There&#x27;s also a fast clean button on the base for a 25-second cleaning for when you&#x27;re really rushed but you&#x27;ll need to wipe the fluid off the unit after as it doesn&#x27;t dry the shaver. The pulsoic action, while very gimmicky sounding, seems effective in getting the trouble hairs to get cut, those hairs that are near impossible to shave due to them being flat laying.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;A note about wet/dry shaving; the Braun is strictly a dry shaver so it cannot be used with shaving creams or gels and cannot be used in the shower. The head can be rinsed under running tap water, that&#x27;s as far as its wet-use properties go. And in my opinion it&#x27;s a good thing. While most shaver makers are rushing to make the best wet/dry shaver, Braun seems intent on focusing to make the best dry-use-only shaver and in this regard I think they&#x27;ve succeeded. Personally, one of the perks ofusing an electric shaver was that I no longer needed my shaving creams, lotions and brushes and the whole shaving process as a result became much quicker (cutting my shaving time in at least half) and a lot less messy. But for those looking for a wet shaver then obviously this shaver isn&#x27;t for them.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;There&#x27;s really not much to add here. This is a superb shaver that I think will work for many people. Shavers are very personal, what works for one person will not necessarily work for another. The foils came in flat packs and you just bend them and pop them into the brushed stainless steel foil holder. I brought quite a few of them with me when I came to the US and I never had any problem with it for the next ten years or so.&lt;br /&gt;Later on I purchased many of the new models which had a few more extra bells and whistles, some convenience features, twin cutting blocks and became cordless and rechargeable which was probably the most significant change for me. But they really could not improve on the performance of the Sixtant since it was so good to begin with, but I was happy with all the other forthcoming models I purchased.&lt;br /&gt;I still have the 7570 model in very good working condition and still holds the charge very well after 11 years, the first one came with the cleaning system (very bad design) which broke after 2-3 months of use, but I felt that the cleaning system on this shaver does not really needed anyway. As long as the cutting block was separate from the foil it was fast, efficient and easy to clean it with the brush. Later I purchased the 8595 model which had a lot better designed jet cleaning system, it was a bit noisier than the 7570 but the performance was the same.&lt;br /&gt;Before I got the 790cc I tried the Philips Norelco 1280X w/jet clean system which is a very nice and quiet shaver, does an excellent job and close shave but I could not get used to the ergonomics and the Braun definitely gives me a touch closer shave, my face felt a lot smoother after shaving even with the Braun 7570.&lt;br /&gt;Finally I decided to get the 790cc the latest and greatest Braun which certainly has a lot of nice features, bells and whistles, easy to use and convenient to clean it with the cleaning system every other day, when the shaver feels and smells fresh, like new. However I enjoy the new design, all the new features, the better ergonomics and the convenience of the clean and renew station.&lt;br /&gt;So I am back to the same brand I have been using for the past 50 years and I am delighted with the performance of this new 790cc shaver and I can honestly say there is no other shaver on the market which gives you this close shave without any skin irritation, highly recommend it to anybody.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Update after almost 3 years:&lt;br /&gt;I still have this Braun 790CC which works well but always has been pretty noisy and although I commented before that it gives me a touch closer shave than the Philips 1280XX it is really a toss up since I just repurchased a new Philips 1280XX/42 and alternately using both of them. They equal in closeness of shave and the Philips appears to be made from better material. On the Braun 790CC some of the nice metal looking parts are silver paint covered plastic and this paint coating is now bubbling up at the back under the cutting head after a couple of years of use and Jet cleaning which is very disappointing. The only thing with the Philips that it gives me a touch more skin irritation sometimes if I am not careful enough around the lower neck area, but very close and extremely quiet shave. No doubt that these 2 shavers are the best on the market today and I will be using both of them alternately for a while and make a final judgement if I will keep both of them or just the one I prefer to use.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Another update after using both the above shaversalternately for 3 weeks:&lt;br /&gt;After 2 weeks of use there was no more skin irritation with the Philips and I had to come to a conclusion that the Philips 1280XX gives me faster, a lot quieter, smoother and even a bit closer shave than the Braun 790CC. Final word, the Philips 1280XX is the keeper for me.alternately for 3 weeks:&lt;br /&gt;After 2 weeks of use there was no more skin irritation with the Philips and I had to come to a conclusion that the Philips 1280XX gives me faster, a lot quieter, smoother and even a bit closer shave than the Braun 790CC.     <li> UPDATED REVIEW&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;35 years ago my Father told me \\&quot;If Your going to use an electric razor - buy a Braun\\&quot; and so began a relationship with Braun products that up until recently has lasted close to forty years. I was always eager to try the new models, Braun razors were just one of those products that only got better and more innovative as time marched on. When Braun introduced the first cleaning/charging system for the 8585 model, I bought one immediately and loved it. When the Pulsonic came out I bought the 790cc and as you can see from my review below I adored it.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;What set Braun apart from every single other electric razor on the planet was it&#x27;s foil and cutting block - which really did last their promised 18 months. For those that remember the multi patented Optifoil was unlike anything else on the market. Instead of uniform, same shaped holes. The foil had a wide variety of different shapes. Circles, half moons, crescents, stars and so on. It seemed random in placement but there was a method to the madness  and you really ended up with a blade close shave.The foil and cutter (linear blades designed by Gillette) when it comes to performance the cutting block and foil is the very heart of any electric razor.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Being both a head and face shaver, I prefer a wet shave with a DE (double edge) safety razor or straight blade. But the process is time consuming. The small appliances division was closed down. Manufacturing of the electric razors was terminated in Germany and resumed in China with the exception of the 760 &amp; 790cc which are still, at least for the time being made in Germany.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;P&amp;G scrapped the original foil and replaced it with the generic series 7 one.     <li> Before I start off, it might be useful to understand the difference between electric shaving and shaving using the conventional razor for those who have not experienced the both.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Using the razor, we usually apply some kind of a lubricant like gel or foam. Using the electric razor, I have found the lubricant to be optional. Using the razor we essentially wipe the blade over the shaving area, while using the electric razor I feel, it is more like a scrub. The scrubbing does not necessarily mean that the skin would get irritated more but for some people and brands of electric shavers, it does. If there is any skin irritation/burn 1% Hydrocortisone ointment provides relief in a matter of minutes.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Applying lubricant may also not always get you better results in all shaving zones when using an electric shaver. However, sometimes it does. If you apply a lubricant and shave with an electric shaver, the cleaning process may take you a little extra bit of effort.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;A quick note on the shaving foam vs. the Gels - For me the conventional foam yields better results than the newer gels. The cheapest Gillette shaving lather yielded better results than the much more expensive Neutrogena gels. Therefore, you may want to experiment especially before you settle for an expensive product.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;At this point, it might be useful to mention that I switched to the 790cc shaving system after having used Philips/Norelco-Razor for 18 long years. My facial hair is not one of the toughest but is oriented randomly enough to make my shave hard to do a perfect job especially using an electric shaver.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;I classify my shave into four zones based on the hair types/difficulties I encounter:&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Zone 1 - on the cheeks: Shaving is easy in this zone and I have been able to get close shaves by several means wet and dry/electric and razor shavers.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;However, Norelco were nasty on this seemingly straightforward job. The shaves were usually not perfect and if I tried to shave multiple times, the razor burn would be nasty. The discomfort went to the extent that I had to actively research and discovered the Hydrocortisone and it became a norm.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;With Braun, this area is a piece of cake as it should be and there is no need to apply steroids any more. Also notable is the fact that the number of scrubs it takes is considerably less than a Norelco - almost the same number of strokes is required as the conventional razor. Using a shaving foam/gel further reduces the number of strokes and the subsequent skin irritation.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Zone 2 - the chin &amp; below the cheeks: Hairs in this zone seem tougher but the reality is that the hairs grow closer to the skin to be harder to pick. For me the random orientation begins here. Here Braun is clearly superior to a Norelco and comes very close to the conventional razor in terms of the number of strokes and related skin irritation.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;The pressure of application of an electric razor in this zone is considerably higher. However, with 790cc the increased pressure would not result in a razor burn. Any attempt to mimic the results of 790cc with a Norelco may result in severe skin burn and irritation. I would therefore switch to a razor with Norelco in this zone.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Zone 3 - the moustache: My moustache is is sensitive and the lining with the upper lip if irritated would take considerable time to calm down. There also seem to be some random oriented hairs and then of course are the ones that are otherwise perfectly visible but hide along the nose when it comes to shaving! Along the nose, Norelco shaves the best as its circular cutters can find hairs better. However, 790cc did not lag too far behind if I allowed a few extra strokes, which is easy to do, as the burn factor is absent.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;790cc is also benign on my upper lip lining, Norelco and conventional razors were outright nasty! On the flat areas my experiences were a mixture of Zone 1 and 2 with 790cc faring the best.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Zone 4 - the neck: Even though 790cc does a much better job than the Norelco, I feel that the conventional razor is the champion of the shave on the neck. 790cc however does produce acceptable results with some foam applied. If you have to the time to shave pinched skin, you will get the same results as the razor. You may not want to try Norelco in this area since the resultant burn may last for days and the shaving might need a razor to complete.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Now a word on the cleaning system. If you want the liquid inside it to last, always rinse the 790cc under hot water and shake it to remove water before you put the 790cc in the cleaner. I did find traces of shaved hair under the foil after a full clean cycle. I do clean the foil with a brush and detergent once every 2 weeks. If you tried to clean the cavity in the cleaning system every other week, you would find good amount of smudge there as well. I consider this normal. However, what I do not like about this system is paying for the cleaning cartridge every month. I therefore perfected an 85% rubbing alcohol, 10% glycerin and 5% lemon oil (all purchased from a drug store) concoction for my cartridge that seems to work well and save me the monthly charge. Do not use other forms of denatured alcohol as some of the preparations may contain potentially dangerous additives. Some people have reported that mouthwash also works well but I doubt that since the mouthwash are water based.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Well so much for the review. Hope you enjoy the 790cc!0cc faring the best.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Zone 4 - the neck: Even though 790cc does a much better job than the Norelco, I feel that the conventional razor is the champion of the shave on the neck. 790cc however does produce acceptable results with some foam applied.     <li> I&#x27;ve accumulated quite a few electric razors over the years, with the three most recent being the new models from Norelco, Braun and Panasonic. So, thought I&#x27;d do a comparison to perhaps help those who are debating between these high-end models.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;But first let&#x27;s get a basic question out of the way: do you have to spend this much to get a good shave from an electric shaver? Absolutely not. Lower-end models such as the Braun Series 5, the 7000 and 8000 Norelco series and the Panasonic ArcIV are great shavers. What you get for the extra money is a slight improvement in the shave, a bit better design, and a few somewhat useful bells and whistles.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Build quality - all are very nicely put together. The Braun feels the most substantial; the 3D feels the most &amp;#34;plasticy.&amp;#34;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Sound - the 3D runs very quietly; the Braun and Panasonic are far more &amp;#34;buzzy&amp;#34; but not too loud.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Overall feel - for me, the Braun feels the most comfortable to hold. Easy to grip even if your hands are wet. The Panasonic is a close second. The 3D feels the most awkward. Not horrible, but not all that comfortable either.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Dry shave: closeness - this is a tough call, with the Braun and the Panasonic both providing very close shaves. The 3D does a pretty good job, but my face does not feel as smooth as with the others.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Dry shave: speed - the 3D is the clear winner here. Just mows through my beard, with a total shave time of less than 3 min. The Panasonic takes about 4 min for a good shave; the Braun clocks in at about 5 min.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Dry shave: neck - this is the most difficult area for most shavers, and all of these models left a few errant hairs here and there. The 3D did the best but it comes at the expense of some irritation (see the next note). The Braun and Panasonic are about equal.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Dry shave: comfort - Braun is the winner for me, followed by the Panasonic. Zero redness even in the more sensitive spots (jaw line and neck). The 3D left me with some red spots on my neck. Nothing severe, but it is clearly a notch below the others on the comfort meter.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Wet shave - this is limited to just the Panasonic and the 3D. I&#x27;m not a big fan of wet shaving, but both of these do a very good job. The Panny works best with a very thin layer of gel-type cream; the 3D works best with a heavier lather (I got good results with Edge). Both provided close shaves, with the Panny a bit more gentle than the 3D. But, the 3D did a better job on the neck and jaw line.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;**Update: Just tried the new Remington Alphagel shaving cream and that works very well with both the Panny and the Norelco. The scent is a bit heavy (menthol) but the no-foam consistency is a perfect match for a wet electric shave. Much better than any other shave cream I&#x27;ve tried. I reviewed the Alphagel if you want more info.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Maneuverability - this is where the Braun really shines for me. I have a mustache, and edging it with the Braun is a piece of cake. The 3D takes some practice, but it can do a decent job. Worst by far was the Panasonic - the huge head makes it very hard to create a clean edge around the &#x60;stash.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Auto cleaning - I love the cleaning station from Braun. Works well, cleans well, and the razor comes out lemony-fresh. The Panasonic cleaning station is OK, but is louder, takes longer, and the water-based cleaning solution is not as effective. I can&#x27;t comment on the 3D station since the model I bought didn&#x27;t come with it.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Manual cleaning - both the Panasonic and 3D are very easy to clean manually. They actually don&#x27;t need the auto cleaning station (although it is handy for storage for the Panny). The cutters are removable from the 3D (unlike the Arcitec models) for extra cleaning every so often. The Braun can be cleaned with water, but it&#x27;s hard to get it very clean since the cutter block is a single unit.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Lots more that I could say about these razors, but this review is already way too long. If I had to pick just one, I&#x27;d go with the Braun. While not perfect, it excels in several areas and feels the best. It also offers three settings (gentle, normal and intensive) that vary the speed of the cutters, a feature the other two lack. I find that very helpful. Plus, replacement heads are easily available and often discounted (as are the cleaning cartridges). But, the 3D and the Panasonic are also very good shavers and will get the job done. If you are willing to spend the money, any one of these would be a good choice.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Note: I have the Braun 790cc-4 since I was able to get it at a fantastic price (on another site - sorry Amazon!) on Black Friday. But, under normal pricing situations, the 760 is cheaper and a better value. They work the same, with the differences limited to color of the razor, type of read-out on the handle, and the fact that the 760 lacks the &amp;#34;quick clean&amp;#34; feature in the cleaning station. None of these are really significant, so if you go with the Braun, pick the one that is cheaper.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;But, you have to learn how to use an electric razor properly to get a good shave. Some quick tips:&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;1) Don&#x27;t press hard - use an easy touch. If the heads are getting warm or hot, you&#x27;re pressing too hard.&lt;br /&gt;2) Shave against the grain when using a foil; shave in circular motions when using a rotary.&lt;br /&gt;3) Stretch your skin taut when shaving your neck&lt;br /&gt;4) Wait at least an hour after getting up before shaving (everyone&#x27;s face gets a bit puffy when sleeping).&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Happy shaving!&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&amp;#62;&amp;#62;Update June 2012: Thought I&#x27;d post an update after 1.5 years of use. In addition, this uses up the fluid rather quickly and the cartridges are not cheap.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;My solution (no pun intended) is to simply pop the razor head off after each shave, give it and the razor a quick rinse, shake them out and then place it in the charger and let it do the clean. Not sure if thats the foil design or what, but it&#x27;s a noticeable thing for me.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Trimmer works well, is a bit smaller (width-wise) than other&#x27;s I&#x27;ve had, and it flips out (not slides up) so that it&#x27;s perpendicular to the shaver body. The shaver, however, is quite different from the previous designs. The body of the unit is a sculpted/circular shape, unlike the rectangular bodies before -- similar to the rotary shavers. It feels very comfortable in the hand, and is easy to grip due to the textured material on the sides of the body. It has a very substantial feel, and a good weight and balance to it. The pop-up trimmer doesn&#x27;t extend up vertically, but rotates up from the front of the body. The foil and cutter block are now integrated into 1 unit called a cartridge, and can&#x27;t be manually taken apart if you want to clean them by hand. How does it shave? It shaves twice as close as my old series 5 did when the foil and cutter were brand new. I would dare to say that it shaves almost as close as a blade. -- and this is the first electric shaver that I would say that about. The shaver reeks of quality -- both in design and construction. The noise and vibration are similar to my old series 5, which is fine with me. I was never bothered by either, although some other folks here feel different. If you need a new shaver, I would give this one a close look. I was lucky and got an instant $40 rebate, which made this a no-brainer. I will mention that I was also looking at wet/dry shavers by Braun and Panasonic. The reason that I didn&#x27;t go with those (everyone unanimously agrees that the shave is better and closer when done wet with gel than dry) is due to the fact that those models can&#x27;t be run off a cord if the battery dies, for safety reasons. When you&#x27;re on the road, or if the battery goes, you&#x27;ll be without a working shaver.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;** Update 7/22/2014 **&lt;br /&gt;This shaver continues to impress after 1 month. Every shave has the same closeness. This machine really does shave as close as a blade -- no joke. The cleaning function works even better than before. I don&#x27;t bother with a preliminary manual cleaning before running a cleaning cycle, as I always did with my old series 5. It kills me to spend so much money on a new shaver, but this thing really does shave like a champ.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;** update 11/08/2014 **&lt;br /&gt;The best shave I ever had. Every time I use this machine I find myself murmuring \\&quot;this is an amazing shave\\&quot;. Shaving time is now cut in half due to not needing to reshave previous areas as much. Since the product has already been reviewed in great length I wanted to focus my review on one particular aspect that seems to stir up some controversy: wet vs dry shave.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;There are some that use this razor as a wet razor meaning they use it to shave with shaving foam, gel, or other like products. Others, rightfully so, point out that this model is not rated as a wet shaver and uphold that 1) the razor would not perform well \\&quot;wet\\&quot; since it&#x27;s not designed to shave with foam and 2) that \\&quot;wet\\&quot; shaving might damage the unit.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Fact is, there is only one model in the Series 7 lineup that is officially rated as a wet shaver, the 7-799cc. Unfortunately, that model is not available in the US and Canada. At least not at the time this review was written and since the 7-799cc has been out for a while now I doubt it will come to the US at all.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Having said that, all the Series 7 models use the exact same shaver head (Braun only makes one for the 7 series) and the same pulsonic shaving mechanism. The ONLY difference between the 7-799cc and other Series 7 models is the amount of water insulation of the shaver itself.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;The body of the 7-799cc is completely water insulated and can be completely immersed in water. The unit can therefor safely be used in the shower. That is NOT the case for the other Series 7 models which should NOT be used in the shower since water can get into the power plug hole and damage the shaver.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;That aside, all models are completely water insulated around the shaver head. Braun advises to rinse the shaver head under running water with the shaver turned on (although unplugged for safety reasons) for manual cleaning. The user manual also states that it is ok to rinse the shaver with a mild soap solution. Obviously, alcohol based solutions (which have very low surface tension) aren&#x27;t a problem either since that is what the cleaning station uses. Exposing the shaver head to shaving foam/gel etc would therefor not be any more of a problem than cleaning the shaver manually by rinsing it under running water, soap, or alcohol.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;That means all Series 7 models are fine to be used as a \\&quot;wet\\&quot; shaver as long as one does not expose the unit to more water than one would when manually cleaning it per manufacturer instructions. In other words do NOT use it in the shower and keep water off the body of the razor. As far as shaving performance goes, the 7-790cc would perform identical to the 7-799cc.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Whether you should use it as a wet shaver comes down to personal preference.     <li> This is a review more of the Braun return process (which is bad) than of the shaver itself (which could be great for you, but didn&#x27;t work well for me). The return process is part of the shaver experience, and it seemed worthy of documentation.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;THE SHAVER&lt;br /&gt;I purchased this shaver in September, having shaved manually for a number of years and wanting to speed up my grooming. I have a fairly thick beard, and various online guides and reviews suggested that this was one of the better shavers on the market. The cleaning solution smelled great, the automatic cleaning process seemed to work well, and the entire setup looked cool in my bathroom. The shaver itself did a great job on my face but couldn&#x27;t shave fairly large sections of my neck, despite many passes from many angles, varying degrees of pressure, and weeks of acclimation.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;THE RETURN PROCESS&lt;br /&gt;Different shavers work well for different people, so most consumer shavers come with money-back guarantees. The Braun is no different: you have 60 days to try it out, and if you&#x27;d like to return it, you can. Unfortunately, I found the return process frustrating and ultimately misleading. My experience was as follows:&lt;br /&gt;1. Search online for &amp;#34;braun 60 day money back guarantee.&amp;#34; The top hit is the return form pdf. Off to a good start!&lt;br /&gt;2. Read the return form, looking for a return address. Seems like an obvious place to put it, but no dice.&lt;br /&gt;3. Call the number listed on the form, then navigate four layers deep into their automated phone system. Eventually find the recorded message that reveals the return address after making you listen to much of the return form.&lt;br /&gt;4. Call the number back again and re-navigate the phone system and re-listen to the whole message, since the address is only read to you once (fairly quickly) and then the system hangs up on you.&lt;br /&gt;5. Call the number a third time and re-navigate/re-listen to check the address I have written down.&lt;br /&gt;6. Punch the address into Google Maps to increase confidence in its correctness, since I&#x27;m about to mail a fairly expensive gizmo to this address and I haven&#x27;t actually seen it printed anywhere. Pump fist when the address exists.&lt;br /&gt;7. Repack my shaver and accessories, walk it down to the Post Office, and pay to mail it and track it.&lt;br /&gt;8. Check Post Office tracking status a few days later to learn that it arrived safely somewhere, hopefully where it needs to be.&lt;br /&gt;9. Wait for ~5 weeks without hearing anything.&lt;br /&gt;10. Call the Braun customer service number and speak with someone about the status of my return. They found my return in the system, which pleased me, and told me that it was being processed. No timeline estimate was available.&lt;br /&gt;11. Receive in the mail a prepaid Citi card for the amount I paid Amazon, after about 6 weeks.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Steps 1-10 could have been (much) better, but Step 11 broke the camel&#x27;s back. I purchased a Norelco shaver earlier this year, and when I took advantage of its money-back guarantee, I received a check in the mail. I didn&#x27;t have to call a number to activate the check, the money that the check conferred didn&#x27;t expire or have maintenance fees, there was no PIN to memorize, it was simple to combine the funds from the check with other funds to pay for something expensive - in other words, it was just my money back, which is exactly what was advertised.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;But the prepaid card I received from the Braun money-back guarantee has all of those features, and seems like a poor substitute for getting my money back. Thus, the process continued:&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;12. Call Braun customer service, express my confusion about getting a crippled card when I wanted my money back. Ask if this switcheroo is buried in fine print anywhere, or if they just do this. Be informed that it&#x27;s not printed anywhere, but that&#x27;s their policy, and there&#x27;s nothing that they can do about it.&lt;br /&gt;13. Think on this for a few minutes, then call Braun customer serviceagain and speak with someone else about it. Receive the same story again, and hear that I don&#x27;t actually need to activate the card that says &amp;#34;You must activate your card prior to use.&amp;#34; The jury is still out on this one.&lt;br /&gt;14. Write this review on Amazon, with the hope that people will be better aware of how the return process works and that Braun and Proctor &amp; Gamble will make this experience more user-friendly.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Best of luck with your shaving and/or returning!again and speak with someone else about it. Receive the same story again, and hear that I don&#x27;t actually need to activate the card that says &amp;#34;You must activate your card prior to use.&amp;#34; The jury is still out on this one.&lt;br /&gt;14. I know that the average person may not have a compressor... But if you do, this is the very best way to clean the shaver.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;2. Always clean the razor head before you use the Clean &amp; Renew system. If you don&#x27;t, the reservoir can become pretty disgusting.I know it sounds crazy to say clean the shaver before you clean it... What I really mean is to remove the excess debris. Tap the base of the saver head on a hard surface and poke around with the brush that comes with the shaver to remove the as much of the hair as possible.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;3. You can find pretty good prices on Amazon for the Clean and Renew replacement cartridges... But it&#x27;s still not a cheap date. Like the cartridges in an ink jet printer, the liquid will evaporate and you will have to frequently replace them. A neat trick that I have found can really reduce the frequency of replacement. New cartridges have plugs that have to be removed when installed. I now keep the plugs. I insert the cartridge, clean the razor, and then remove the cartridge and put the plugs back in. This prevents evaporation and greatly extends the life of the cartridge. In addition, evaporation concentrates the yucky residue. So preventing evaporation tends to keep the solution cleaner as well.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;4. When it comes to the quality of the shave... I have never had a better shave from an electric razor. That being said, I would agree with some reviews that state that the Pulsonic does not handle an extra day&#x27;s growth as well as the older Braun models. I find it helps to make a first pass without pressing the razor tightly to the skin and then go back and do the finish cut so to speak.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Hope this info helps perspective buyers.t printer, the liquid will evaporate and you will have to frequently replace them.     <li> I had a Series 5 razor for almost 4.5 years, and decided to upgrade because I needed to both replace the foil/cutter assembly and the charging/cleaning base, which was no longer cleaning properly (all the stubble would just collect at the bottom and not go into the cartridge).  Although comparing a well-used Series 5 with a new Series 7 probably isn&#x27;t fair, the Series 7 provides a much better shave.  It takes fewer strokes, shaves more closely, and is smoother.  Again, hard to know whether that&#x27;s all due to the features/performance of the Series 7 or the age of the razor it replaced, but I have no regrets.  In addition, the Series 7 (790cc model, at least) comes with a nice and compact, semi-hard, zippered case; some earlier runs appear to have come with a much cheaper plastic case.  (Not sure why Braun does this, but I&#x27;ve been using their razors for over 25 years, and the quality of the travel cases waxes and wanes.  Fortunately, a good quality case right now.)  There are a few downsides: There is no little plastic cover that clips over the foil when traveling, so it&#x27;s not as well protected.  The trimmer is step backwards.  It extends out so far (and is narrower than those on the Series 5) that it magnifies movement and is harder to control.  I suspect I&#x27;ll get used to it eventually.  The button to extend the trimmer also is right where my thumb rests when shaving, so you have a tendency to push the trimmer out/open when shaving unless you pay attention.  But for those quibbles, a real improvement over the Series 5.  It&#x27;s worth noting that the battery in the 790cc is lithium ion battery.  The 790cc also has an electronically controlled sensitivity/power function, which controls the intensity/speed of the pulsations, as far as I can tell.  Seems to work, but I just use the medium setting.  The swivel lock function (lock either on or off) makes more sense than the three-position switch on the Series 5.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Amazon&#x27;s price for the 790cc right now is so good that it&#x27;s hard to justify getting a lower model Series 7, since they are about the same price.  The Series 5 is significantly cheaper (by about $50), and served me well, but I think that the extra amount for the Series 7 at Amazon.com&#x27;s price is worth it.
